text: there's headline-grabbing news in the
fight against cervical cancer with
research claiming that up to 90 of cases
can be avoided through the use of
vaccination researchers in england have
been studying a program to jab young
teenagers against the hpv virus which
can trigger the disease and they say the
positive effects have already become
apparent as dominic hughes now reports
almost all cases of cervical cancer are
linked to the human papillomavirus the
hpv vaccine program targeting the virus
itself was introduced in the uk in 2008
when girls aged between 11 and 13 were
first off of the jab and since september
2019 boys of the same age have also been
eligible
now the first real-world study of the
vaccine shows it's had a dramatic effect
cervical cancer rates were 87 lower in
girls who were offered the vaccine when
age 12 and 13. it's estimated that by
mid-2019 the hpv jab program had
prevented around 450 cervical cancers
and around 17
200 pre-cancers all of which would have
needed some medical intervention
this study looked at people who both had
the vaccine for hpv and were screened by
cervical cancer so cervical screening
still remains important and as the
vaccine
gets taken up more and more people are
vaccinated we might see changes to what
the screening program looks like so that
might be how often you go in or what the
test looks like but for now it's still
really important that if you're invited
to circle screening to consider going
currently cervical cancer claims the
lives of around 850 women in the uk
every year but the researchers believe
that in the future a combination of the
vaccine and screening could mean hardly
anyone goes on to develop the disease
they say it's a testament to the power
of science to protect the lives of
thousands of women dominic hughes bbc
news
